title: Chandni Naidu
text:
Welcome to my website.
I’m a designer and researcher, I study how technology reshapes the relationship between people, institutions, and power—particularly in fintech, platform labor, and government service delivery. My work sits at the intersection of sociology, design, and political economy, with a focus on India and the majority world.
Previously: Design Manager at Aspire ($15B TPV fintech), research lead on financial inclusion in Indonesia, design faculty, and founder of an edtech startup. Masters in HCI from IIT Bombay, MicroMasters from MIT Economics.
On this website, I write data essays, dive into rabbit holes, and collect evidence of thoughtfulness in built environments.
More about me

title: Chandni Naidu
text: This is a research website built with Quarto and hosted on GitHub Pages. It features my research and design reports, including interactive data visualizations, reproducible analyses, and references.

title: Data & Code
text:
How to Reproduce

Option 1: Clone the Repository
git clone https://github.com/chandniverse/chandniverse.github.io.git
cd chandniverse.github.io
Then open chandniverse.github.io.Rproj in RStudio.


Option 2: Download Individual Files
Download the specific scripts and data files you need from the tables above.


Option 3: Run in R
# Install required packages
install.packages(c("ggplot2", "plotly", "dplyr", "knitr"))

# Source the analysis script
source("scripts/analysis.R")

title: Data Analysis
text: This page demonstrates interactive data visualization using ggplot2 and plotly. The approach follows best practices for reproducible research (Wickham, 2016; Xie et al., 2018).

title: Data Analysis
text: This page demonstrates interactive data visualization using ggplot2 and plotly. The approach follows best practices for reproducible research (Wickham, 2016; Xie et al., 2018).

title: Data Analysis
text:
Setup


Code
library(ggplot2)
library(plotly)
library(dplyr)

title: Data Analysis
text:
Interactive Scatter Plot
The following visualization explores the relationship between vehicle weight and fuel efficiency in the mtcars dataset.


Code
p <- ggplot(mtcars, aes(x = wt, y = mpg, color = factor(cyl), 
                         text = paste("Car:", rownames(mtcars)))) +
  geom_point(size = 3, alpha = 0.7) +
  geom_smooth(method = "lm", se = FALSE, linetype = "dashed") +
  scale_color_brewer(palette = "Set1") +
  labs(
    x = "Weight (1000 lbs)",
    y = "Miles per Gallon",
    color = "Cylinders"
  ) +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(legend.position = "bottom")

ggplotly(p, tooltip = c("text", "x", "y"))








Figure 1: Interactive scatter plot showing the relationship between weight and MPG, colored by number of cylinders




As shown in Figure 1, there is a clear negative relationship between vehicle weight and fuel efficiency. Vehicles with more cylinders tend to be heavier and less fuel-efficient.

title: Data Analysis
text:
Distribution Analysis


Code
p2 <- ggplot(mtcars, aes(x = mpg, fill = factor(cyl))) +
  geom_histogram(binwidth = 2, alpha = 0.7, position = "identity") +
  scale_fill_brewer(palette = "Set2") +
  labs(
    x = "Miles per Gallon",
    y = "Count",
    fill = "Cylinders"
  ) +
  theme_minimal()

ggplotly(p2)








Figure 2: Distribution of MPG values across all vehicles

title: Data Analysis
text:
Box Plot Comparison


Code
p3 <- ggplot(mtcars, aes(x = factor(cyl), y = mpg, fill = factor(cyl))) +
  geom_boxplot(alpha = 0.7) +
  geom_jitter(width = 0.2, alpha = 0.5) +
  scale_fill_brewer(palette = "Pastel1") +
  labs(
    x = "Number of Cylinders",
    y = "Miles per Gallon",
    fill = "Cylinders"
  ) +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(legend.position = "none")

ggplotly(p3)








Figure 3: Comparison of MPG across different cylinder counts

title: Data Analysis
text:
Summary Statistics


Code
mtcars %>%
  group_by(Cylinders = cyl) %>%
  summarise(
    `Mean MPG` = round(mean(mpg), 2),
    `SD MPG` = round(sd(mpg), 2),
    `Mean Weight` = round(mean(wt), 2),
    `N` = n()
  ) %>%
  knitr::kable()




Table 1: Summary statistics by cylinder count

Mean MPG
SD MPG

title: Data Analysis
text:
Methods
The analysis was conducted using R (R Core Team, 2023) with the following packages:

ggplot2 for static visualizations (Wickham, 2016)
plotly for interactive features
dplyr for data manipulation

title: Data Analysis
text:
Conclusions
This exploratory analysis reveals several key patterns:

Weight-efficiency trade-off: Heavier vehicles consistently show lower fuel efficiency
Cylinder effect: More cylinders correlate with both higher weight and lower MPG
Variation: 4-cylinder vehicles show the highest variation in fuel efficiency







Reproducibility



All code in this analysis is fully reproducible. Download the source files from the Data & Code page.

title: Data Analysis
text:
References


R Core Team. (2023). R: A language and environment for statistical computing.


Wickham, H. (2016). ggplot2: Elegant graphics for data analysis.


Xie, Y., Allaire, J. J., & Grolemund, G. (2018). R markdown: The definitive guide.

title: Bookshelf
text: A collection of books I’ve read and would recommend, organized by year.

title: Bookshelf
text:
2026
Welcoming more serendipity in my book choices this year.





She Who Became the Sun
Shelley Parker-Chan
Reading: January 2025
I seem to be drawn to historic fiction based in East Asia.







In Every Mirror She’s Black
Lola Akinmade Åkerström
Read: January 2025
Three Black women from different places end up in Sweden for different reasons, on different terms, and get to see Swedish society for what it is.

title: Bookshelf
text:
2025





Take My Hand
Dolen Perkins-Valdez
Read: December 2025
A book that taught me (once again) that fiction and narrative are more powerful tools to grasp the gravity of uncomfortable historic events and social facts.







Best Of Friends
Kamila Shamsie
Read: December 2025
Girls everywhere are the same, and ones from the Indian subcontinent are particularly plucky. I enjoyed the stories of two friends in Pakistan, all the way from girlhood in Karachi to rich professional careers in London.







Americanah: A novel
Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie
Read: October 2024
This book made everything simultaneously better by validating my observations about Americans, and worse by not redeeming them from my already unflattering impression.

title: Bookshelf
text:
2024





The Poppy War
Rebecca F Kuang
Read: 2024
A special cross between fantasy, magial realism and historic fiction, such a treat for anybody who enjoys these genres. If you’re unfamiliar with history China, Korea and Japan, you may not make the connections, but if you do, it will be cathartic and poetic, you’ll love how beautifully the story addresses deep, shared wounds.







Em and the Big Hoom
Jerry Pinto
Read: January 2025
We take life as it comes, and we write about it like it will be the most important story ever told.

title: Bookshelf
text:
2023





Coming Out As Dalit
Yashica Dutt
Read: 2023
Likely the majority experience in India, such little representation in Indian literature.







Illustration: What’s the Point?: A Book of Illustrated Illustrations that Illustrate Illustration
Mouni Feddag
Read: 2023
A book for the soul that sometimes wonders – what’s the point anyway.







The Ivory Throne: Chronicles of the House of Travancore
Manu S. Pillai
Read: 2023 Historically important nuances that everybody, especially Dravidians should know about matrilineal culture.

title: Chandni Naidu
text: Blog

title: Quarto X GitHub
text:
This might be it. For man years, I’ve struggled to leave “platforms” and with every effort to leave, I hurt my self-expression and end up feeling more isolated and less expressed. Maybe I needed to go through those experiences to reaffirm to myself just how important it is that I feel… properly expressed. That I have a space to write, share my art, while also respecting my existential need to not be an inmate in a substack or instagram jail. Communities built on those platforms don’t feel like communities, so why would I invest in them? I’m still open to cross-posting, but they absolutely cannot be my primary house for my digital self to reside in. eugh, what a disgustingly low standard that is, to not have your own digital home where you can live on your own terms. Less than 0.1% of individuals have managed to build a digital presence on their terms, and most content creators use platforms that meet their goals, so they’re happy to sign away their rights.
My goals are somewhat different, I might even sound impossible to please. - I want to share ideas, journal entries, thoughts, notes from episodes of existential dread, memos from hopeful times, and art that is special to my people because I made it. - I want to see the same from people I care about, whether or not I know them irl. - For many people, instagram, substack, twitter, tumblr serve these needs perfectly well. Unfortunately, I’m a technology researcher and with every minute i spend on those platforms, it feels like willingly hanging out in a gas chamber. It’s okay if you don’t know its a slow-acting gas chamber, you’ll maybe even enjoy being lulled into a gentle death. But when you know, it’s different. Let’s just say survival instinct is very strong. In other words, I need to achieve goals 1 and 2 without using a social media platform. - Am I okay with an email-list? I think so, but I’m going to invest in reciprocity. I want my readers to also cultivate their digital rights, so I can be part of their lives on dignified terms. - I write long-form text, but I also write a lot of charts, data visualizations. It’s part of my thinking process.
After bumbling around in the weeds of the internet, testing several tools that cleverly disguise the fact that they’re platforms, I’ve decided that I’m comfortable hosting my content on GitHub (yes, I know Microsoft owns it, it’s very much a platform, but I’m free to move my content anywhere anytime without being trapped, so this works for me) I will pay for my domain, and when I die and my credit card doesn’t work anymore, my content will continue to live in my github universe, chandniverse.github.io
Last year, when I was actively in a job search, I felt the pressure to neatly compartmentalise my professional persona from my other dimensions, but I’m not feeling that pressure anymore. I also know that the next job(s) that I might pursue will be the kinds where having an authentic digital personality will be a sign of good-fit.
So here it is, my new home. No launch parties, I’m going to quietly push this commit and leave it here for when somebody gets curious at some point - why does she write here? Like this?
Well, now you know.

title: About
text:
Hello, I’m Chandni, a researcher and designer who has spent twelve years moving building tech products, and from the insider experience of knowing how business models are built, I ask uncomfortable questions about them. It’s led me to a more critical study technology systems: how platforms govern labor, how fintech reshapes economic institutions, how governments digitize their relationship with citizens.
I’m interested in aspects of tech that get regulated, automated, obscured or even weaponised. My research combines computational methods with political economy frameworks, focused on India and comparative global contexts.
The through-line: I’m drawn to complex systems and the human decisions embedded within them.
I was born and raised in Chennai and have since lived in Delhi, Mumbai, Bangalore, Berlin, Nairobi, and now New York. I’m an insatiably curious person who often finds herself deep in rabbit holes and tries to bring back interesting stories—sometimes as data essays, sometimes as illustrated children’s books, sometimes as obsessively detailed digital archives on hyper-specific topics. Hence this website, a digital-garden, an archive of intellectual adventures.
Outside of tech, I maintain a rotating set of hobbies: printmaking, brush lettering, botanical illustration, designing little apps for friends, volunteering at the local library and public schools. I get excited by good metaphors, unexpected connections, and discovering small acts of thoughtfulness in the built environment.
This site is where I keep my research, writing, past projects, and ongoing experiments. Some of it is polished; some of it is thinking in public, starting conversations. If you’re interested in technology and society, design as inquiry, or the occasional well-constructed tangent—welcome. I hope you find something worth staying for.

title: About
text:
About This Site
This website is built with Quarto, an open-source scientific and technical publishing system. It’s designed to showcase reproducible research with interactive data visualizations. It also hosts Chandni’s blog, which are also likely to contain charts and images.
